content:
Look at this theorem. How can one deduce from that theorem that whenever hhh and h′h'h′ are both composites of fff and ggg, then hhh is homotopic to h′h'h′?

Recall that a simplicial set XXX is called a contractible Kan complex if the unique map X→Δ0X\to \Delta^0X→Δ0 is a trivial Kan fibration. In the above theorem I interpret "contractible Kan complex" as something like "essentially a singleton", so that intuitively, the theorem says that the space of all composition witnesses σ\sigmaσ with d2σ=fd_2\sigma = fd2​σ=f and d0σ=gd_0\sigma = gd0​σ=g is essentially a singleton. (And intuitively, if such a σ\sigmaσ is unique, then in particular the composition h=d1σh=d_1\sigmah=d1​σ of fff and ggg is unique, which motivates the first question.)

Does that make sense: is a trivial Kan fibration something like a bijection, isomorphism, or equivalence between simplicial sets? If not, what is a trivial Kan fibration intuitively?

Let GGG be a directed graph and C\mathcal CC an ∞\infty∞-category. This theorem says that there exists a trivial Kan fibration Fun⁡(N⁡∙(Path⁡[G]),C)→Fun⁡(G∙,C)\operatorname{Fun}( \operatorname{N}_{\bullet }( \operatorname{Path}[G] ), \mathcal{C}) \rightarrow \operatorname{Fun}( G_{\bullet }, \mathcal{C})Fun(N∙​(Path[G]),C)→Fun(G∙​,C). (Fun⁡\operatorname{Fun}Fun denotes exponential objects, Path⁡[G]\operatorname{Path}[G]Path[G] is the path category of the directed graph GGG, and G∙G_\bulletG∙​ is the ≤1\leq 1≤1-dimensional simplicial set corresponding to GGG.) Does that imply that there is a bijection between the functors (simplicial maps) from N⁡∙(Path⁡[G]) \operatorname{N}_{\bullet }( \operatorname{Path}[G])N∙​(Path[G]) to C\mathcal CC and the simplicial maps from G∙G_\bulletG∙​ to C\mathcal CC? (A related fact I know is that an inner anodyne map is a bijection on vertices.)

Leopold Schlicht said:

Look at this theorem. How can one deduce from that theorem that whenever hhh and h′h'h′ are both composites of fff and ggg, then hhh is homotopic to h′h'h′?

If you apply the definition of a trivial Kan fibration in the case n=1n=1n=1 to this situation, you obtain a map Δ2×Δ1→C\Delta^2\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal{C}Δ2×Δ1→C constant on Λ21×Δ1\Lambda_2^1\times\Delta^1Λ21​×Δ1 (that is, a homotopy between the compositions, seen as 2-simplices); in particuar, you obtain the homotopy between the composites you're looking for as the restriction along d1×idΔ1 ⁣:Δ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1d_1\times\mathrm{id}_{\Delta^1}\colon\Delta^1\times\Delta^1\hookrightarrow\Delta^2\times\Delta^1d1​×idΔ1​:Δ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1.

Does that imply that there is a bijection between the functors (simplicial maps) from N⁡∙(Path⁡[G]) \operatorname{N}_{\bullet }( \operatorname{Path}[G])N∙​(Path[G]) to C\mathcal CC and the simplicial maps from G∙G_\bulletG∙​ to C\mathcal CC? (A related fact I know is that an inner anodyne map is a bijection on vertices.)

Not a bijection in general: consider the case G∙=Λ21G_\bullet =\Lambda_2^1G∙​=Λ21​, so that Path[G]=Δ2\mathrm{Path}[G]=\Delta^2Path[G]=Δ2 (as above, injectivity is up to homotopy).
A trivial Kan fibration is a special sort of equivalence.

@Andrea Gentili Thanks!

If you apply the definition of a trivial Kan fibration in the case n=1n=1n=1 to this situation, you obtain a map Δ2×Δ1→C\Delta^2\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal{C}Δ2×Δ1→C constant on Λ21×Δ1\Lambda_2^1\times\Delta^1Λ21​×Δ1 (that is, a homotopy between the compositions, seen as 2-simplices); in particuar, you obtain the homotopy between the composites you're looking for as the restriction along d1×idΔ1 ⁣:Δ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1d_1\times\mathrm{id}_{\Delta^1}\colon\Delta^1\times\Delta^1\hookrightarrow\Delta^2\times\Delta^1d1​×idΔ1​:Δ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1.

What do you mean by "to this situation"? The only thing I can imagine is the following: let σ\sigmaσ be a witness of h=g∘fh=g\circ fh=g∘f and σ′\sigma'σ′ be a witness of h′=g∘fh'=g\circ fh′=g∘f. Since Fun⁡(Δ2,C⁡)×Fun⁡(Λ12,C⁡){(g,∙,f)}\operatorname{Fun}( \Delta ^2, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) \times _{ \operatorname{Fun}( \Lambda ^2_1, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) } \{ (g, \bullet , f) \}Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ12​,C)​{(g,∙,f)} is a contractible Kan complex, every map ∂Δ1→Fun⁡(Δ2,C⁡)×Fun⁡(Λ12,C⁡){(g,∙,f)}\partial \Delta^1\to \operatorname{Fun}( \Delta ^2, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) \times _{ \operatorname{Fun}( \Lambda ^2_1, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) } \{ (g, \bullet , f) \}∂Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ12​,C)​{(g,∙,f)} can be extended to a map Δ1→Fun⁡(Δ2,C⁡)×Fun⁡(Λ12,C⁡){(g,∙,f)}\Delta^1\to \operatorname{Fun}( \Delta ^2, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) \times _{ \operatorname{Fun}( \Lambda ^2_1, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) } \{ (g, \bullet , f) \}Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ12​,C)​{(g,∙,f)}. Now we could plug in (σ,σ′)(\sigma, \sigma')(σ,σ′) as the map ∂Δ1→Fun⁡(Δ2,C⁡)×Fun⁡(Λ12,C⁡){(g,∙,f)}\partial \Delta^1\to \operatorname{Fun}( \Delta ^2, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) \times _{ \operatorname{Fun}( \Lambda ^2_1, \operatorname{\mathcal{C}}) } \{ (g, \bullet , f) \}∂Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ12​,C)​{(g,∙,f)}. But I don't see how a map of the type Δ2×Δ1→C\Delta^2\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal{C}Δ2×Δ1→C appears.

@Mike Shulman Thanks. Can you make that more precise?
Any trivial Kan fibration is a simplicial homotopy equivalence. See for instance Corollary 1.4.5.5 here.

I didn't know that that's what is called a "simplicial homotopy equivalence". Thanks. I interpret this corollary as saying that a trivial Kan fibration is (surjective) and (injective up to homotopy) (as Andrea already said).

You understood correctly. Once you have the map Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21,C){(g,∙,f)}\Delta^1\to\mathrm{Fun}(\Delta^2 ,\mathcal C)\times_{\mathrm{Fun}(\Lambda_2^1 ,\mathcal C)}\{ (g,\bullet ,f)\}Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21​,C)​{(g,∙,f)}, you have to keep in mind that Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21,C){(g,∙,f)}\mathrm{Fun}(\Delta^2 ,\mathcal C)\times_{\mathrm{Fun}(\Lambda_2^1 ,\mathcal C)}\{ (g,\bullet ,f)\}Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21​,C)​{(g,∙,f)} can be seen as a subspace of Fun(Δ2,C)\mathrm{Fun}(\Delta^2 ,\mathcal C)Fun(Δ2,C), so that you have a map Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C)\Delta^1\to\mathrm{Fun}(\Delta^2 ,\mathcal C)Δ1→Fun(Δ2,C), that, by adjunction, gives you the map Δ2×Δ1→C\Delta^2\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal CΔ2×Δ1→C.

Thanks! I now see how to get the map Δ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1→C\Delta^1\times\Delta^1\hookrightarrow\Delta^2\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal CΔ1×Δ1↪Δ2×Δ1→C. Are you then using Corollary 1.3.3.7 to obtain a homotopy h→h′h\to h'h→h′ from that map Δ1×Δ1→C\Delta^1\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal CΔ1×Δ1→C?

Mike Shulman said:

Any trivial Kan fibration is a simplicial homotopy equivalence. See for instance Corollary 1.4.5.5 here.

Ah, here is that statement. Also, if both the domain and the codomain of a trivial Kan fibration are ∞\infty∞-categories, then the trivial Kan fibration is an equivalence of ∞\infty∞-categories.

Are you then using Corollary 1.3.3.7 to obtain a homotopy h→h′h\to h'h→h′ from that map Δ1×Δ1→C\Delta^1\times\Delta^1\to\mathcal CΔ1×Δ1→C?

Yes (the conditions of the corollary are satisfied since the original map factorizes through Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21,C){(g,∙,f)}\mathrm{Fun}(\Delta^2,\mathcal C)\times_{\mathrm{Fun}(\Lambda_2^1,\mathcal C)}\{ (g,\bullet ,f)\}Fun(Δ2,C)×Fun(Λ21​,C)​{(g,∙,f)}).
